prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
Example:
Question:
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Phoenix Wright
Description: My first client. Just standing in front of this guy makes me nervous...
Character 1
Name: Shadi Smith
Description: The victim in this case. A traveler, only recently back in-country.
Character 2
Name: Winston Payne
Description: The prosecuting attorney. For all his experience, he lacks a certain presence...
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Post-Mortem Report
Description: Death occurred a little after 2 p.m. and was caused by loss of blood from a gunshot to the chest. The bullet did not pass through the victim's body.
Evidence 1
Name: Photograph of Victim
Description: A photographic print that shows the victim. He was shot from the front in the chest and subsequently died.
Evidence 2:
Name: Crime Scene Photograph
Description: A bottle of carbonated water and a steak lunch can be seen on the victim's table.
Evidence 3:
Name: Medical Report Card
Description: A record of dental work. On the day of the murder, the victim had undergone dental treatment and been prohibited from eating or drinking anything but water.
Evidence 4:
Name: Photograph of Handbag
Description: A photograph taken by Hosonaga-san after the incident occurred. It shows Miss Brett's handbag on a chair by the victim's table.
Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: I was ingesting a regulation beef steak at the restaurant while having a tactical discussion with the old man.
Person: Nosa
Testimony 1
Testimony 1: Myself, I was extolling the virtues of a particularly fine golden curio to the military gentleman.
Person: Korekuta
Testimony 2
Testimony 2: At that precise moment, a firearm was discharged! I observed the enemy's actions with my own eyes!
Person: Nosa
Testimony 3
Testimony 3: The black-uniformed varsity cadet fired on the English civilian! And from the back, the cowardly little weasel!
Person: Nosa
Testimony 4
Testimony 4: I was on my hands and knees, investigating the where-abouts of my mysteriously absconded precious curio.
Person: Korekuta

Answer:
Let's think step by step:
Let's analyze the evidence and testimonies provided.
Testimony 3 states that the gun shot was fired "from the back". However, Evidence 0, which is "Post-Mortem Report," states that the victim died "from a gunshot to the chest", which implies that the witness is lying.
{"evidence": 0, "testimony": 3}
Question:Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Yujin Mikotoba
Description: A medical school professor at the Imperial Yumei University. He's an authority in forensic medicine, and Miss Susato's father.
Character 4
Name: Seishiro Jigoku
Description: The Minister of Foreign Affairs and a judge of the Supreme Court of Judicature in Japan. He's the man who acquitted me when I was once accused of murder.
Character 5
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 6
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 7
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A mostly reformed pickpocket who's now a self-appointed 'detective inspector'. She's really making waves in her new apprenticeship.
Character 8
Name: Evie Vigil
Description: A client who has engaged the services of Mr Sholmes. She has asked the great detective to help track down her missing husband.
Character 9
Name: Daley Vigil
Description: A man who's disappeared without a word to his family. He was the former chief warder of Barclay Prison.
Character 10
Name: Barry Caidin
Description: The governor of Barclay Prison. It seems he was good friends with Professor Mikotoba during the Japanese man's time in Britain as a visiting student.
Character 11
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: A murdered Scotland Yard inspector. He was stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 12
Name: Kazuma Asogi
Description: My best friend, who I had believed to be dead. He lost his memory somehow, but has now materialised as a prosecutor in the British courts.
Character 13
Name: Gossip
Description: A pedlar plying his trade on Fresno Street. He seems to make his money selling interesting items of news to passers-by.
Character 14
Name: Venus
Description: A pedlar plying her trade on Fresno Street. She seems to make her money selling meagre little fireworks to children.
Character 15
Name: Sandwich
Description: A mysterious 'signpost' who can be found on Fresno street. He looks familiar somehow...
Character 16
Name: Fabien de Rousseau
Description: The fraudster behind the Red-Headed League swindle, who was caught by Mr Sholmes. He derives from the French aristocracy, it seems.
Character 17
Name: Peppino de Rossi
Description: A lackey of de Rousseau and conspirator in the Red-Headed League swindle. The third son of a great Italian landowner.
Character 18
Name: Maria Gorey
Description: The daughter of Dr Sithe who's also a coroner like her mother. She carries out all the autopsy work on corpses.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Red-Headed League Article
Description: An advertisement from the newspaper that's entitled 'To the Red-Headed League'. It seems somewhat suspicious in nature.
Evidence 2
Name: Photograph of Mr Vigil
Description: A photographic print received from Mrs Vigil in order to aid with locating her missing husband. He appears to have no particularly distinctive facial features.
Evidence 3
Name: Letter of Introduction
Description: A note of introduction on our behalf from Professor Mikotoba to Governor Caidin. Hopefully now he'll be willing to talk to us. A note of introduction on our behalf from Professor Mikotoba to Governor Caidin. It's written on the back of a ticket for passage on a steamship.
Evidence 4
Name: Dismissal Notice
Description: The harsh reprimand incurred by Mr Vigil ten years ago that resulted in him losing his job as chief warder of Barclay Prison.
Evidence 5
Name: Red Hairpiece
Description: A flame-red wig found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Presumably it belonged to Inspector Gregson...
Evidence 6
Name: Candelabrum
Description: A candelabrum from the wall of the room on Fresno Street where the inspector was found dead. The top of one of the candles appears to have been blown off.
Evidence 7
Name: Revolver
Description: The murder weapon that was found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Probably best to avoid handling it.
Evidence 8
Name: Policeman Figurine
Description: A small and rather endearing model of a British policeman found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. A model of a British policeman found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Giving it a twist causes a key-like shaft to pop out from the base.
Evidence 9
Name: Framed Photograph
Description: A photographic print of a smiling Mrs Vigil in her younger years. It was found on a desk at the scene of the crime.
Evidence 10
Name: Gregson's Photograph
Description: An old photographic print displayed rather prominently in Inspector Gregson's office, as if it was a treasured memory. An old photographic print displayed rather prominently in Inspector Gregson's office. The person on the left is Lord Klint van Zieks.
Evidence 11
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: Inspector Gregson's autopsy report, stating that death was instant, resulting from a bullet shot at close range. The autopsy report from the examination of Inspector Gregson's body. According to the coroner, Dr Gorey, an accurate estimation of the time of death is not possible.
Evidence 12
Name: Crime Scene Floor Plan
Description: A plan of the small room in the building of flats on Fresno Street where the body of the victim, Inspector Gregson, was found.
Evidence 13
Name: Noticeboard
Description: A free-standing noticeboard completely covered in notes and articles relating to victims of the Reaper of the Bailey. A free-standing noticeboard completely covered in notes and articles relating to victims of the Reaper. There is a bloody handprint on the back side.
Evidence 14
Name: Venus Firecracker
Description: The Venus Special firecracker consisting of one hundred smaller fireworks at sixpence each. What sort of bang could it make...? The Venus Special firecracker consisting of one hundred smaller fireworks at sixpence each. It goes off like a gunshot.
Evidence 15
Name: Photograph of the Victim
Description: A photographic print of the victim, Inspector Gregson. His body appears to be tightly curled up and there's a red hairpiece on his head.
Evidence 16
Name: Gregson's Pocket Watch
Description: Inspector Gregson's pocket watch that he wound without fail every single day. It's no longer ticking and the glass over the face is cracked. Inspector Gregson's pocket watch that he wound without fail every single day. Having wound it up, it's started ticking again.
Evidence 17
Name: Inspector's Identification
Description: The identification of a man claiming to be a detective inspector, confiscated by Mr de Rousseau and Mr de Rossi. Inspector Gregson's police identification. It's the official warrant card issued to him by Scotland Yard.
Evidence 18
Name: Commemorative Photograph
Description: A photograph taken in the foyer of the Great Waterloo Hotel on the morning of Professor Mikotoba and Judge Jigoku's arrival in London for the symposium.
Evidence 19
Name: The Asogi Papers
Description: The last will and testament of Genshin Asogi that Mr Vigil claims disappeared after the convict's execution. Apparently Mr Asogi described it as 'the only weapon I have left'. The last will and testament of Genshin Asogi that Mr Vigil claims disappeared after the convict's execution. It seems there was a third page to it.
Evidence 20
Name: Gregson's Trunk
Description: Inspector Gregson's metal travelling trunk that was removed from the scene, but subsequently recovered by Gina.
Evidence 21
Name: Passport
Description: A passport document that was in Inspector Gregson's possession. It was issued for travel to France the day before his body was discovered.
Evidence 22
Name: Klint's Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the final victim of the infamous Professor. The report was authored by Dr John H. Wilson. The report from the autopsy of the Professor's final victim. It's signed by Dr John H. Wilson who carried out the procedure, though Professor Mikotoba actually penned the report.
Evidence 23
Name: Iris's Lucky Charm
Description: A little doll of Mr Sholmes in hare form. I've been told to tug its ears if I run out of options in the trial today...
Evidence 24
Name: Great Sword 'Karuma'
Description: The illustrious blade passed down through generations of the Asogi clan. The prized sword's tip has a small piece missing.
Evidence 25
Name: Evacuation Drill Itinerary
Description: A notice about a practice evacuation to be carried out by the crew of the SS Grouse the night before the ship arrived in Dover. It was found in Judge Jigoku's cabin.
Evidence 26
Name: Small Component
Description: A small machine part that Mr Sholmes found in Judge Jigoku's cabin on the SS Grouse. A small machine part that Mr Sholmes found in Judge Jigoku's cabin on the SS Grouse. It's now clear that it's the missing 'crown' of Inspector Gregson's pocket watch. * (This update to the description is entirely optional, and can only be achieved by examining anywhere on this evidence, then the tip on Gregson's Pocket Watch before the former evidence is specifically presented in court. However, this method still occurs in Story Mode.)
Evidence 27
Name: Telegram from Japan
Description: A telegram from Inspector Hosonaga in Japan with details of the telegram he managed to locate by stealing into Judge Jigoku's office.
Evidence 28
Name: Mr Asogi's Ring
Description: A ring belonging to Genshin Asogi found in Lord Klint van Zieks's stomach during the autopsy. The claws clasping the gem look sharp enough to cause a very nasty scratch.
Evidence 29
Name: Klint van Zieks's Will
Description: The last will and testament of Lord Klint van Zieks that has been hidden inside the great sword Karuma for years. A trump card left behind by Genshin Asogi.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: We saw the whole thing from start to finish, we did. Everything from the moment they went in the building.
Person: Gossip
Testimony 1
Testimony: It was less than a minute after the Reaper had gone inside that we all 'eard a big bang.
Person: Venus
Testimony 2
Testimony: Seems to m-me that quick-to-talk is quick-to-walk. Gossip couldn't wait to go and see what had happened.
Person: Sandwich
Testimony 3
Testimony: I ran into the room and there he woz. The Reaper, gun in hand, standin' over the dead body!
Person: Gossip
Testimony 4
Testimony: I slipped over and got blood on my hand, so I quickly wiped it off on the floor.
Person: Gossip
Testimony 5
Testimony: I was scared 'alf to death, me. So I ran off to find a copper.
Person: Venus

Answer:
Let's think step by step:
cot:
Let's analyze the evidence and testimonies provided.

Testimony 0 states that Gossip and presumably others "saw the whole thing from start to finish, ... Everything from the moment they went in the building." This implies they had a clear view of the people entering the crime scene.

Evidence 12, Crime Scene Floor Plan, however, is a plan of a "small room" in the building of flats on Fresno Street. In previous Ace Attorney cases, a small room with no windows or clear vantage points from the outside would logically make it impossible for witnesses on the street (such as Gossip) to view the events happening inside from "start to finish," let alone "everything from the moment they went in the building."

Therefore, Gossip's testimony contradicts the physical evidence of the scene.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: I don't know anythin' about that there noticeboard! I just wiped my hand on it, that's all.
Person: Gossip
Testimony 1
Testimony: Well don't look at me. I 'aven't got a clue about it. I was doin' business with some second years at the time.
Person: Venus
Testimony 2
Testimony: Maybe I did sneak along behind Gossip and 'ave a little peek into the room where it all 'appened.
Person: Venus
Testimony 3
Testimony: I, I don't know anything about anything. I'm j-just a bystander, me. J-Just a sign at the crossroads of life.
Person: Sandwich
Testimony 4
Testimony: It woz that Reaper, I bet. He's got a face that screams 'board'.
Person: Gossip
Testimony 5
Testimony: I c-can't see how this changes anything anyway. The detective still died w-when we heard the gunshot.
Person: Sandwich

Answer:
Let's think step by step:
cot:
Let's start by examining both the evidences and the testimonies for possible contradictions.

Evidence 13, the Noticeboard, has "a bloody handprint on the back side." Testimony 0, by Gossip, says, "I don't know anythin' about that there noticeboard! I just wiped my hand on it, that's all." If he "just wiped his hand on it," that could explain the presence of a handprint, but the handprint is *bloody*. Gossip doesn't mention anything about blood, which may be a slight contradiction, but it's plausible he omitted that detail.

Let's review Testimony 5 by Sandwich: "The detective still died w-when we heard the gunshot."

Now, let's reference Evidence 11, which is "Inspector Gregson's autopsy report, stating that death was instant, resulting from a bullet shot at close range. The autopsy report...an accurate estimation of the time of death is not possible."

Testimony 5 claims the detective died "when we heard the gunshot," but the autopsy report specifically states that "an accurate estimation of the time of death is not possible." This means it cannot be definitively said that he died exactly when the gunshot was heard—it is entirely possible, given the ambiguity of the autopsy report, that the gunshot was not simultaneous with the death, or that the time the witnesses heard it is not the true time.

Therefore, Testimony 5 ("the detective still died w-when we heard the gunshot") is contradicted by Evidence 11 ("an accurate estimation of the time of death is not possible").

Question:Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Yujin Mikotoba
Description: A medical school professor at the Imperial Yumei University. He's an authority in forensic medicine, and Miss Susato's father.
Character 4
Name: Seishiro Jigoku
Description: The Minister of Foreign Affairs and a judge of the Supreme Court of Judicature in Japan. He's the man who acquitted me when I was once accused of murder.
Character 5
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 6
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 7
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A mostly reformed pickpocket who's now a self-appointed 'detective inspector'. She's really making waves in her new apprenticeship.
Character 8
Name: Evie Vigil
Description: A client who has engaged the services of Mr Sholmes. She has asked the great detective to help track down her missing husband.
Character 9
Name: Daley Vigil
Description: A man who's disappeared without a word to his family. He was the former chief warder of Barclay Prison.
Character 10
Name: Barry Caidin
Description: The governor of Barclay Prison. It seems he was good friends with Professor Mikotoba during the Japanese man's time in Britain as a visiting student.
Character 11
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: A murdered Scotland Yard inspector. He was stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 12
Name: Kazuma Asogi
Description: My best friend, who I had believed to be dead. He lost his memory somehow, but has now materialised as a prosecutor in the British courts.
Character 13
Name: Gossip
Description: A pedlar plying his trade on Fresno Street. He seems to make his money selling interesting items of news to passers-by.
Character 14
Name: Venus
Description: A pedlar plying her trade on Fresno Street. She seems to make her money selling meagre little fireworks to children.
Character 15
Name: Sandwich
Description: A mysterious 'signpost' who can be found on Fresno street. He looks familiar somehow...
Character 16
Name: Fabien de Rousseau
Description: The fraudster behind the Red-Headed League swindle, who was caught by Mr Sholmes. He derives from the French aristocracy, it seems.
Character 17
Name: Peppino de Rossi
Description: A lackey of de Rousseau and conspirator in the Red-Headed League swindle. The third son of a great Italian landowner.
Character 18
Name: Maria Gorey
Description: The daughter of Dr Sithe who's also a coroner like her mother. She carries out all the autopsy work on corpses.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Red-Headed League Article
Description: An advertisement from the newspaper that's entitled 'To the Red-Headed League'. It seems somewhat suspicious in nature.
Evidence 2
Name: Photograph of Mr Vigil
Description: A photographic print received from Mrs Vigil in order to aid with locating her missing husband. He appears to have no particularly distinctive facial features.
Evidence 3
Name: Letter of Introduction
Description: A note of introduction on our behalf from Professor Mikotoba to Governor Caidin. Hopefully now he'll be willing to talk to us. A note of introduction on our behalf from Professor Mikotoba to Governor Caidin. It's written on the back of a ticket for passage on a steamship.
Evidence 4
Name: Dismissal Notice
Description: The harsh reprimand incurred by Mr Vigil ten years ago that resulted in him losing his job as chief warder of Barclay Prison.
Evidence 5
Name: Red Hairpiece
Description: A flame-red wig found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Presumably it belonged to Inspector Gregson...
Evidence 6
Name: Candelabrum
Description: A candelabrum from the wall of the room on Fresno Street where the inspector was found dead. The top of one of the candles appears to have been blown off.
Evidence 7
Name: Revolver
Description: The murder weapon that was found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Probably best to avoid handling it.
Evidence 8
Name: Policeman Figurine
Description: A small and rather endearing model of a British policeman found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. A model of a British policeman found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Giving it a twist causes a key-like shaft to pop out from the base.

Name: Framed Photograph
Description: A photographic print of a smiling Mrs Vigil in her younger years. It was found on a desk at the scene of the crime.
Evidence 10
Name: Gregson's Photograph
Description: An old photographic print displayed rather prominently in Inspector Gregson's office, as if it was a treasured memory. An old photographic print displayed rather prominently in Inspector Gregson's office. The person on the left is Lord Klint van Zieks.
Evidence 11
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: Inspector Gregson's autopsy report, stating that death was instant, resulting from a bullet shot at close range. The autopsy report from the examination of Inspector Gregson's body. According to the coroner, Dr Gorey, an accurate estimation of the time of death is not possible.
Evidence 12
Name: Crime Scene Floor Plan
Description: A plan of the small room in the building of flats on Fresno Street where the body of the victim, Inspector Gregson, was found.
Evidence 13
Name: Noticeboard
Description: A free-standing noticeboard completely covered in notes and articles relating to victims of the Reaper of the Bailey. A free-standing noticeboard completely covered in notes and articles relating to victims of the Reaper. There is a bloody handprint on the back side.
Evidence 14
Name: Venus Firecracker
Description: The Venus Special firecracker consisting of one hundred smaller fireworks at sixpence each. What sort of bang could it make...? The Venus Special firecracker consisting of one hundred smaller fireworks at sixpence each. It goes off like a gunshot.
Evidence 15
Name: Photograph of the Victim
Description: A photographic print of the victim, Inspector Gregson. His body appears to be tightly curled up and there's a red hairpiece on his head.
Evidence 16
Name: Gregson's Pocket Watch
Description: Inspector Gregson's pocket watch that he wound without fail every single day. It's no longer ticking and the glass over the face is cracked. Inspector Gregson's pocket watch that he wound without fail every single day. Having wound it up, it's started ticking again.
Evidence 17
Name: Inspector's Identification
Description: The identification of a man claiming to be a detective inspector, confiscated by Mr de Rousseau and Mr de Rossi. Inspector Gregson's police identification. It's the official warrant card issued to him by Scotland Yard.
Evidence 18
Name: Commemorative Photograph
Description: A photograph taken in the foyer of the Great Waterloo Hotel on the morning of Professor Mikotoba and Judge Jigoku's arrival in London for the symposium.
Evidence 19
Name: The Asogi Papers
Description: The last will and testament of Genshin Asogi that Mr Vigil claims disappeared after the convict's execution. Apparently Mr Asogi described it as 'the only weapon I have left'. The last will and testament of Genshin Asogi that Mr Vigil claims disappeared after the convict's execution. It seems there was a third page to it.
Evidence 20
Name: Gregson's Trunk
Description: Inspector Gregson's metal travelling trunk that was removed from the scene, but subsequently recovered by Gina.
Evidence 21
Name: Passport
Description: A passport document that was in Inspector Gregson's possession. It was issued for travel to France the day before his body was discovered.
Evidence 22
Name: Klint's Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the final victim of the infamous Professor. The report was authored by Dr John H. Wilson. The report from the autopsy of the Professor's final victim. It's signed by Dr John H. Wilson who carried out the procedure, though Professor Mikotoba actually penned the report.
Evidence 23
Name: Iris's Lucky Charm
Description: A little doll of Mr Sholmes in hare form. I've been told to tug its ears if I run out of options in the trial today...
Evidence 24
Name: Great Sword 'Karuma'
Description: The illustrious blade passed down through generations of the Asogi clan. The prized sword's tip has a small piece missing.
Evidence 25
Name: Evacuation Drill Itinerary
Description: A notice about a practice evacuation to be carried out by the crew of the SS Grouse the night before the ship arrived in Dover. It was found in Judge Jigoku's cabin.
Evidence 26
Name: Small Component
Description: A small machine part that Mr Sholmes found in Judge Jigoku's cabin on the SS Grouse. A small machine part that Mr Sholmes found in Judge Jigoku's cabin on the SS Grouse. It's now clear that it's the missing 'crown' of Inspector Gregson's pocket watch. * (This update to the description is entirely optional, and can only be achieved by examining anywhere on this evidence, then the tip on Gregson's Pocket Watch before the former evidence is specifically presented in court. However, this method still occurs in Story Mode.)
Evidence 27
Name: Telegram from Japan
Description: A telegram from Inspector Hosonaga in Japan with details of the telegram he managed to locate by stealing into Judge Jigoku's office.
Evidence 28
Name: Mr Asogi's Ring
Description: A ring belonging to Genshin Asogi found in Lord Klint van Zieks's stomach during the autopsy. The claws clasping the gem look sharp enough to cause a very nasty scratch.
Evidence 29
Name: Klint van Zieks's Will
Description: The last will and testament of Lord Klint van Zieks that has been hidden inside the great sword Karuma for years. A trump card left behind by Genshin Asogi.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: We 'ad more zan one thousand red-'eaded people assemble in ze park on Lime Street zat day.
Person: De Rousseau
Testimony 1
Testimony: But I don't recall the man in this-a photograph. Ay, capo?
Person: De Rossi
Testimony 2
Testimony: Non, I don't remember 'im. Obviously 'e is dead now. But I assure you, 'e was not in ze park.
Person: De Rousseau
Testimony 3
Testimony: Allora! This victim is-a nothing to do with us!
Person: De Rossi
Testimony 4
Testimony: You 'ave a lot to answer for, Peppino. It is your fault zat we got caught in ze first place.
Person: De Rousseau

Answer:
Let's think step by step:
cot:
Let's review the evidence and testimonies:

Testimony 2 (De Rousseau): "Non, I don't remember 'im. Obviously 'e is dead now. But I assure you, 'e was not in ze park."
Evidence 5 (Red Hairpiece): "A flame-red wig found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Presumably it belonged to Inspector Gregson..."

Since Gregson is apparently dead and not recognized by De Rousseau, let's see if his claim regarding Gregson being "not in the park" fits the evidence. However, the more evident contradiction is between the event the Red-Headed League organized and the testimonies by De Rousseau and De Rossi.

Testimony 0: "We 'ad more zan one thousand red-'eaded people assemble in ze park on Lime Street zat day." (De Rousseau)
Evidence 1: "Red-Headed League Article" — An advertisement entitled 'To the Red-Headed League'. It seems somewhat suspicious in nature.

But there's no direct contradiction there. Let's look for a more blatant contradiction.

Testimony 2: (De Rousseau) "I assure you, 'e was not in ze park." (referring to Inspector Gregson)
Evidence 15: "Photograph of the Victim" — A photographic print of the victim, Inspector Gregson. His body appears to be tightly curled up and there's a red hairpiece on his head.

On closer analysis, the fact De Rousseau claims Gregson "was not in the park" is potentially contradicted by the existence of a Red Hairpiece (Evidence 5) at the crime scene, which is presumably from the Red-Headed League gathering. However, that's circumstantial.

But here's a more direct contradiction:
Testimony 1 (De Rossi): "But I don't recall the man in this-a photograph. Ay, capo?"
Evidence 17: "Inspector's Identification: The identification of a man claiming to be a detective inspector, confiscated by Mr de Rousseau and Mr de Rossi. Inspector Gregson's police identification. It's the official warrant card issued to him by Scotland Yard."

If De Rossi and De Rousseau confiscated Gregson's identification, they must have directly interacted with him and so must recognize him, contradicting Testimony 1.

Therefore, Testimony 1 and Evidence 17 directly contradict each other.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: Ze, ze truth is, we took 'im prisoner and kept 'im for ze night at our secret 'ideout.
Person: De Rousseau
Testimony 1
Testimony: Even though I didn't sink 'e was a real detective, I, I was too scared to let 'im go zat day, just in case.
Person: De Rousseau
Testimony 2
Testimony: We took the man's identification from him and shut-a him in the room next to ours!
Person: De Rossi
Testimony 3
Testimony: Zere might 'ave been a little tussle, but we did 'im no 'arm. And ze next mornin', we let 'im go.
Person: De Rousseau
Testimony 4
Testimony: He tried to escape, but the capo put-a the collare on him and dragged him back...like what he did-a to me, see?
Person: De Rossi
Testimony 5
Testimony: He spent-a the night in a nice room! It was-a nothing like prison really! Uèèèèèè!
Person: De Rossi

Answer:
Let's think step by step:
cot:
Let's examine the evidence and testimonies for contradictions.

Testimony 3 says: "Zere might 'ave been a little tussle, but we did 'im no 'arm. And ze next mornin', we let 'im go."
This claims that the man (apparently Gregson) was held at their hideout overnight and was unharmed, and let go the next morning.

But Evidence 11, the Autopsy Report, says: "Inspector Gregson's autopsy report, stating that death was instant, resulting from a bullet shot at close range. The autopsy report from the examination of Inspector Gregson's body. According to the coroner, Dr Gorey, an accurate estimation of the time of death is not possible."

If Gregson was “let go” the next morning unharmed, but was then found dead (of instant death) after a close-range gunshot, there’s a contradiction about his condition upon leaving their custody. If the autopsy also states "death was instant," and Testimony 3 claims he was unharmed when released, they are contradictory if the timeframe overlaps.

Question:Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Yujin Mikotoba
Description: A medical school professor at the Imperial Yumei University. He's an authority in forensic medicine, and Miss Susato's father.
Character 4
Name: Seishiro Jigoku
Description: The Minister of Foreign Affairs and a judge of the Supreme Court of Judicature in Japan. He's the man who acquitted me when I was once accused of murder.
Character 5
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 6
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 7
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A mostly reformed pickpocket who's now a self-appointed 'detective inspector'. She's really making waves in her new apprenticeship.
Character 8
Name: Evie Vigil
Description: A client who has engaged the services of Mr Sholmes. She has asked the great detective to help track down her missing husband.
Character 9
Name: Daley Vigil
Description: A man who's disappeared without a word to his family. He was the former chief warder of Barclay Prison.
Character 10
Name: Barry Caidin
Description: The governor of Barclay Prison. It seems he was good friends with Professor Mikotoba during the Japanese man's time in Britain as a visiting student.
Character 11
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: A murdered Scotland Yard inspector. He was stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 12
Name: Kazuma Asogi
Description: My best friend, who I had believed to be dead. He lost his memory somehow, but has now materialised as a prosecutor in the British courts.
Character 13
Name: Gossip
Description: A pedlar plying his trade on Fresno Street. He seems to make his money selling interesting items of news to passers-by.
Character 14
Name: Venus
Description: A pedlar plying her trade on Fresno Street. She seems to make her money selling meagre little fireworks to children.
Character 15
Name: Sandwich
Description: A mysterious 'signpost' who can be found on Fresno street. He looks familiar somehow...
Character 16
Name: Fabien de Rousseau
Description: The fraudster behind the Red-Headed League swindle, who was caught by Mr Sholmes. He derives from the French aristocracy, it seems.
Character 17
Name: Peppino de Rossi
Description: A lackey of de Rousseau and conspirator in the Red-Headed League swindle. The third son of a great Italian landowner.
Character 18
Name: Maria Gorey
Description: The daughter of Dr Sithe who's also a coroner like her mother. She carries out all the autopsy work on corpses.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Red-Headed League Article
Description: An advertisement from the newspaper that's entitled 'To the Red-Headed League'. It seems somewhat suspicious in nature.
Evidence 2
Name: Photograph of Mr Vigil
Description: A photographic print received from Mrs Vigil in order to aid with locating her missing husband. He appears to have no particularly distinctive facial features.
Evidence 3
Name: Letter of Introduction
Description: A note of introduction on our behalf from Professor Mikotoba to Governor Caidin. Hopefully now he'll be willing to talk to us. A note of introduction on our behalf from Professor Mikotoba to Governor Caidin. It's written on the back of a ticket for passage on a steamship.
Evidence 4
Name: Dismissal Notice
Description: The harsh reprimand incurred by Mr Vigil ten years ago that resulted in him losing his job as chief warder of Barclay Prison.
Evidence 5
Name: Red Hairpiece
Description: A flame-red wig found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Presumably it belonged to Inspector Gregson...
Evidence 6
Name: Candelabrum
Description: A candelabrum from the wall of the room on Fresno Street where the inspector was found dead. The top of one of the candles appears to have been blown off.
Evidence 7
Name: Revolver
Description: The murder weapon that was found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Probably best to avoid handling it.
Evidence 8
Name: Policeman Figurine
Description: A small and rather endearing model of a British policeman found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. A model of a British policeman found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Giving it a twist causes a key-like shaft to pop out from the base.
Evidence 9
Name: Framed Photograph
Description: A photographic print of a smiling Mrs Vigil in her younger years. It was found on a desk at the scene of the crime.
Evidence 10
Name: Gregson's Photograph
Description: An old photographic print displayed rather prominently in Inspector Gregson's office, as if it was a treasured memory. An old photographic print displayed rather prominently in Inspector Gregson's office. The person on the left is Lord Klint van Zieks.
Evidence 11
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: Inspector Gregson's autopsy report, stating that death was instant, resulting from a bullet shot at close range. The autopsy report from the examination of Inspector Gregson's body. According to the coroner, Dr Gorey, an accurate estimation of the time of death is not possible.
Evidence 12
Name: Crime Scene Floor Plan
Description: A plan of the small room in the building of flats on Fresno Street where the body of the victim, Inspector Gregson, was found.
Evidence 13
Name: Noticeboard
Description: A free-standing noticeboard completely covered in notes and articles relating to victims of the Reaper of the Bailey. A free-standing noticeboard completely covered in notes and articles relating to victims of the Reaper. There is a bloody handprint on the back side.
Evidence 14
Name: Venus Firecracker
Description: The Venus Special firecracker consisting of one hundred smaller fireworks at sixpence each. What sort of bang could it make...? The Venus Special firecracker consisting of one hundred smaller fireworks at sixpence each. It goes off like a gunshot.
Evidence 15
Name: Photograph of the Victim
Description: A photographic print of the victim, Inspector Gregson. His body appears to be tightly curled up and there's a red hairpiece on his head.
Evidence 16
Name: Gregson's Pocket Watch
Description: Inspector Gregson's pocket watch that he wound without fail every single day. It's no longer ticking and the glass over the face is cracked. Inspector Gregson's pocket watch that he wound without fail every single day. Having wound it up, it's started ticking again.
Evidence 17
Name: Inspector's Identification
Description: The identification of a man claiming to be a detective inspector, confiscated by Mr de Rousseau and Mr de Rossi. Inspector Gregson's police identification. It's the official warrant card issued to him by Scotland Yard.
Evidence 18
Name: Commemorative Photograph
Description: A photograph taken in the foyer of the Great Waterloo Hotel on the morning of Professor Mikotoba and Judge Jigoku's arrival in London for the symposium.
Evidence 19
Name: The Asogi Papers
Description: The last will and testament of Genshin Asogi that Mr Vigil claims disappeared after the convict's execution. Apparently Mr Asogi described it as 'the only weapon I have left'. The last will and testament of Genshin Asogi that Mr Vigil claims disappeared after the convict's execution. It seems there was a third page to it.
Evidence 20
Name: Gregson's Trunk
Description: Inspector Gregson's metal travelling trunk that was removed from the scene, but subsequently recovered by Gina.
Evidence 21
Name: Passport
Description: A passport document that was in Inspector Gregson's possession. It was issued for travel to France the day before his body was discovered.
Evidence 22
Name: Klint's Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the final victim of the infamous Professor. The report was authored by Dr John H. Wilson. The report from the autopsy of the Professor's final victim. It's signed by Dr John H. Wilson who carried out the procedure, though Professor Mikotoba actually penned the report.
Evidence 23
Name: Iris's Lucky Charm
Description: A little doll of Mr Sholmes in hare form. I've been told to tug its ears if I run out of options in the trial today...
Evidence 24
Name: Great Sword 'Karuma'
Description: The illustrious blade passed down through generations of the Asogi clan. The prized sword's tip has a small piece missing.
Evidence 25
Name: Evacuation Drill Itinerary
Description: A notice about a practice evacuation to be carried out by the crew of the SS Grouse the night before the ship arrived in Dover. It was found in Judge Jigoku's cabin.
Evidence 26
Name: Small Component
Description: A small machine part that Mr Sholmes found in Judge Jigoku's cabin on the SS Grouse. A small machine part that Mr Sholmes found in Judge Jigoku's cabin on the SS Grouse. It's now clear that it's the missing 'crown' of Inspector Gregson's pocket watch. * (This update to the description is entirely optional, and can only be achieved by examining anywhere on this evidence, then the tip on Gregson's Pocket Watch before the former evidence is specifically presented in court. However, this method still occurs in Story Mode.)
Evidence 27
Name: Telegram from Japan
Description: A telegram from Inspector Hosonaga in Japan with details of the telegram he managed to locate by stealing into Judge Jigoku's office.
Evidence 28
Name: Mr Asogi's Ring
Description: A ring belonging to Genshin Asogi found in Lord Klint van Zieks's stomach during the autopsy. The claws clasping the gem look sharp enough to cause a very nasty scratch.
Evidence 29
Name: Klint van Zieks's Will
Description: The last will and testament of Lord Klint van Zieks that has been hidden inside the great sword Karuma for years. A trump card left behind by Genshin Asogi.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: Ze man who claimed to be an inspector zat day... was definitely not zis man.
Person: De Rousseau
Testimony 1
Testimony: Is right, si! You think we would-a forget these grand lips, uh?
Person: De Rossi
Testimony 2
Testimony: I never leave Fresno Street, alright? I've no interest in any Red-Headed League.
Person: Gossip
Testimony 3
Testimony: Aye, I rent the room where that fella was found, it's true. For what difference it makes.
Person: Boone
Testimony 4
Testimony: I'm all alone in the world, me. I've no kinfolk or nothing. Why would I be involved in something like that?
Person: Gossip/Boone
Testimony 5
Testimony: Just look at me, eh. Doz it look like I could carry off a disguise with a face like this?
Person: Gossip/Boone

Answer:
Let's think step by step:
cot:
Let's analyze the evidence and testimonies.

Testimony 0 from De Rousseau says, "Ze man who claimed to be an inspector zat day... was definitely not zis man." This means De Rousseau is claiming that the person who presented himself as Inspector Gregson was NOT actually Gregson.

However, Evidence 17, "Inspector's Identification," says: "The identification of a man claiming to be a detective inspector, confiscated by Mr de Rousseau and Mr de Rossi. Inspector Gregson's police identification. It's the official warrant card issued to him by Scotland Yard."

If De Rousseau confiscated the official identification from the man and it's genuine Gregson's ID, then the man must have been Gregson himself, contradicting De Rousseau's testimony.
